content:
I wanted to quickly look up a reference for tactics in lean/mathlib, and the two links I found were great for mathlib3/lean3 - https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib_docs/tactics.html and https://lean-lang.org/reference/tactics.html , but the corresponding lean4 versions of these resources https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/ and https://lean-lang.org/lean4/doc/ don't seem to have similar information (unless I couldn't find it). As an aside, improving these docs would be super helpful!

Anyone have a handy link for lean4 tactics? Googling "lean4 tactics reference" didn't result in any fruitful hits.
Known Todo item

I think that

https://github.com/haruhisa-enomoto/mathlib4-all-tactics/blob/main/all-tactics.md

is what is available now. You can also type #help tactic to see the same output, I think.
Thanks!
Alex Kassil has marked this topic as resolved.

@Damiano Testa That is not maintained. I created a latest version of Mathlib tactic list

https://github.com/Seasawher/mathlib4-tactics

My tactic list is automatically updated every day! (thanks to @Oliver Butterley)

Asei Inoue said:

atest version of Mathlib tactic list

https://github.com/Seasawher/mathlib4-tactics

The actual list is viewable at: https://seasawher.github.io/mathlib4-tactics/

There are plans to improve the formatting, grouping, etc.
I think that some tactics may not be defined in Mathlib.Tactic, so maybe you could simply import Mathlib.
What's an example? I thought that Mathlib.Tactic was kept in sync somehow?
I'm pretty sure that I've seen "local" tactics, maybe in the WittVectors part?
I'll look at the diff between #help tactic with the two imports once I'm back at a computer.
docs#WittVector.Tactic.ghostCalc, maybe?

As a curiosity, I would love to know what tactics exist but aren't in Mathlib.Tactic!

However, an easy to read list of tactics isn't useful for advanced Mathlib users, the primary audience are beginners and less experienced users. Consequently the tactics which have been hidden from Mathlib.Tacticare probably the ones best excluded from this list.

When I got some spare time I was hoping to do something to make the list more useful, for example scraping Mathlib to get data on which tactics are used more than others so the list can display the most used tactics and the ones which are barely ever used are still listed but not so prominently. Also newly introduced tactics could be automatically highlighted.
You might also want to check out Tao's https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Gsn5al4hlpNc_xKoXdU6XGmMyLiX4q-LFesFVsMlANo/

It should be easy to write a linter what would flag "tactics", or at least most of them.

There is something weird in the page with tactics: Defined in makes me think that this will be a path (or module name), but it seems to be the name of the declaration.

Maybe, #help tactic could be enriched to output also the module where the tactic is defined and then the output of import Mathlib #help tactic could be used to find tactics not in Mathlib.Tactic.

Also apparently, what #help tactic scrapes is the comment before the main command definition. But there is often more explanations at the top of the file. If this can't be included automatically (and probably it should not because it's directed at the dev audience), then wouldn't it be worthwhile to copy relevant passages from there to the main docstring? Example: #15691

https://github.com/dx2102/mathlib4-tactics-list/tree/main

I organized the list of Lean tactics and commands printed by #help into markdown. I also used python to roughly sort and visualize them by frequency of use, and slightly modified #help to print the file where each syntax is defined. However, I haven't set up github actions to automatically update these for the time being.

In fact, the code of #help looks quite short.

import Mathlib
import Lean

open Lean Meta Elab Tactic Command Mathlib.Tactic

syntax withPosition("#myhelp " colGt &"cats" (colGt ppSpace Parser.rawIdent)) : command

private def elabHelpCat (catStx : Ident) : CommandElabM Unit := do
  let catName := catStx.getId.eraseMacroScopes
  let some cat := (Parser.parserExtension.getState (← getEnv)).categories.find? catName
    | throwErrorAt catStx "{catStx} is not a syntax category"
  liftTermElabM <| Term.addCategoryInfo catStx catName

  let mut msg := MessageData.nil
  let line := Format.line
  let env ← getEnv

  for (name, _) in cat.kinds do
    -- name : SyntaxNodeKind, where SyntaxNodeKind is a `Lean.Name`
    -- let headTk := do getHeadTk (← (← env.find? name).value?)
    let headTk := env.find? name >>= ConstantInfo.value? >>= getHeadTk
    let headTk := headTk |>.getD "..." |>.trim

    let mod ← findModuleOf? name
    let mod := mod |>.map Name.toString |>.getD "..."

    msg := (
      msg
      ++ m!"{headTk}"
      ++ line
      ++ m!"{mkConst name}"
      ++ line
      ++ m!"{mod}"
      ++ line
    )

    if let some doc ← findDocString? env name then
      msg := msg ++ doc.trim ++ line
    msg := msg ++ "----help----" ++ line

  logInfo msg

elab_rules : command | `(#myhelp cats $(id)) => elabHelpCat id

#myhelp cats tactic
#myhelp cats command

I found that formalising mathematics 2024 was also helpful for my study. It has now been mostly updated from Lean3 to Lean4.

https://www.ma.imperial.ac.uk/~buzzard/xena/formalising-mathematics-2024/Part_C/Part_C.html
I'm sure there's a number of people who have compiled such a list already. What would be really useful is if someone put one on the community website

i.e if somebody (@Deming Xu ?) feels like it, it's just forking this repo and then work with the lean4 branch; and probably add a tactics.md file somewhere under templates/ and link that in the corresponding places.

Reviewing wise, you could consider first making a PR with just a few tactics, so that the reviewer can decide on the layout choices and have a follow-up PR with a comprehensive list of tactics, but that's just a suggestion
There should be work in progress adding the tactic documentation to the docgen output, but I'm not recalling what state that is in right now. lean4#4490 is one component.
That would be nice, but should we wait for that?
It would be nice to coordinate. I believe the main people working on it are @David Thrane Christiansen and @Rob Lewis.
@Ralf Stephan Yes, tactic docstring improvements are welcome!

I'm sure there's a number of people who have compiled such a list already. What would be really useful is if someone put one on the community website

I made a tactic list too. (https://seasawher.github.io/mathlib4-tactics/)

However, the output of the #help command itself leaves me dissatisfied. Some of the tactics are completely undocumented, and the meta-information output is inadequate.

I think we need to make fundamental improvements.

There should be work in progress adding the tactic documentation to the docgen output, but I'm not recalling what state that is in right now. lean4#4490 is one component.

nice!!

I guess you shouldn't put my list on the community site. Maybe you can use Asei Ioune's list, or wait for the official version of doc-gen4.

My tiny Python program for counting occurrences of tactics, while useful, is too ad hoc, and it even counts words that appear in comments... I think the correct way to count occurrences is to use metaprogramming in Lean to iterate over the Lean.Elab.InfoTree of each lean file. But in that case I have to go back to read and modify the code at https://github.com/semorrison/lean-training-data ...
We don't need perfection, we need something

If someone wants to contribute it to doc-gen, we have set up the infrastructure in core: https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/pull/4490 and the doc-gen steps are as follows:

  1. Extend the per-module JSON that doc-gen generates with information about which declarations count as tactics with possibly additional meta information about them https://github.com/leanprover/doc-gen4/blob/main/DocGen4/Output/ToJson.lean#L31-L36
  2. Extend the global declaration-data.bmp index with this information
  3. Add an additional command to the doc-gen CLI that get's called after the indexing step is done: https://github.com/leanprover/doc-gen4/blob/main/lakefile.lean#L228. This command would read the global index and then based on it output a tactic.html that contains all of your global information.
  4. Fix a TODO here: https://github.com/leanprover/doc-gen4/blob/b61771aaa8f15bce5e3a38aebeb6dda487f4f29c/DocGen4/Output/Navbar.lean#L75
And please let me know if the part of it in core needs to be modified to make this work well.

@Ruben Van de Velde

We don't need perfection, we need something

Just a link to my list would suffice as a tentative list, and I think that is a change anyone could make.
Yes, and feel free to add my list or the link to it as a temporary solution if you feel it is necessary.

Asei Inoue said:

Just a link to my list would suffice as a tentative list, and I think that is a change anyone could make.

I think this type of thing wasn't considered acceptable, because it means that doc-gen hard-code something about mathlib.
Not in doc gen, on the community website

What is #help and how is it used? I have read most of Theorem Proving in Lean 4 and Functional Programming in Lean 4 and I haven't seen it. Also searching the Lean 4 Manual doesn't give any hits.

Using it in a .lean file just gives the error:

Lean 4:Error:unexpected token '#'; expected command

import Mathlib
#help tactic

Ruben Van de Velde said:

import Mathlib
#help tactic
